column1: Leduc () is a city in the province of Alberta
column2: Canada. It is 33 km (21 mi) south of the provincial capital of Edmonton and is part of the Edmonton Metropolitan Region.

column1: The establishment of the Calgary and Edmonton Railway
column2: later acquired by the Canadian Pacific Railway
column3: opened the region to settlement. The first train stopped at Leduc in July 1891.

column1: Originally there were two versions to describe how Leduc got its name. In fact both accounts are true. In April 1886 when a settler (McKinley) setting up a telegraph office needed a name for the new station and decided that it would be named after the first person who came through the door of the telegraph office. That person was Father Hippolyte Leduc
column2: a priest who had served the area since 1867. Five years later
column4: the Minister of the Interior and Superintendent of Indian Affairs
column5: who had been Lieutenant-Governor of the North-West Territories
column7: was given a list of names
column8: that had been provided to the railroad by Father Lacombe
column9: decided that Telford Place should be renamed at the time the railway terminal was being established. Father Leduc's name was on the list and since the telegraph station was all ready called Leduc Dewdney saw no reason why not to use Leduc's name for the new railroad station and the hamlet that was growing alongside .

column1: Leduc was incorporated as a village in 1899
column2: and became a town in 1906. It became a city in 1983; by that time its population had reached 12

column1: The town continued to grow quietly over the decades and Alberta's historical oil strike on February 13
column3: occurred near the town at the Leduc No. 1 oil well.

column1: Leduc has a wide variety of parks and sports amenities
column2: and has more than 35 km (21.7 mi) of multiuse pathways. On the east end of the city lies Telford Lake
column3: and just to the east is Saunders Lake.

column1: The City of Leduc is a founding member of the Leduc-Nisku Economic Development Association
column2: an economic development partnership that markets Alberta's International Region in proximity to the Edmonton International Airport. The city forms part of this international transportation and economic region. It is on the CANAMEX Trade Corridor at the intersection of two Canadian Pacific Railway lines and is adjacent to the Edmonton International Airport. These transportation links support the petrochemical activities in Alberta's Industrial Heartland

column1: The City of Leduc has its own fire services and emergency management departments. Led by a fire chief
column2: the Fire Services Department comprises full and part-time members providing fire
column3: ambulance and patient transportation services to the city and portions of Leduc County to the west
column4: south and east.The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) provide police services
column5: supported by the city's Enforcement Services Department
column6: which consists of Peace Officers appointed by the Alberta Solicitor General.

column1: Leduc experiences a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfb) closely bordering on a subarctic climate (Dfc). Summers are typically warm and rainy with cool nights. Winters are typically long
column3: and very dry with moderate snowfall. Precipitation usually peaks during July
column4: which is also the sunniest month.

column1: When cannabis was to be federally legalized on October 17th
column3: the City of Leduc needed to inform residents about local public consumption and retail bylaws. On September 19th
column4: 2018 approximately one month prior to the legalization
column5: the City of Leduc introduced residents to a new character “Buddy” via a Facebook post as part of their Cannabis: Need to Know campaign. Buddy’s role was to inform residents of the rules and bylaws surrounding Cannabis use in Leduc. The City’s official Facebook post drew a lot of attention to the campaign with upwards of 24
column7: 000+ hits to the City of Leduc website. Buddy was a personified cannabis leaf’s drawn in the style of a cartoon. He wore blue gloves and blue shoes.

column1: Buddy was not received well by all residents. There was concern from citizens that Buddy’s appearance made cannabis use as a whole appealing to younger demographics. On September 20th a second post was made with a revised version of the character designed to look more authoritative with a clipboard of rules as well as an officer’s style hat.
Three days after the Buddy controversy began
column2: Mayor Bob Young noted that the intended purpose of the spokesbud was “creating conversation in our community that will help ensure people follow the rules”. Within a week
column4: 2018 at a Committee of the Whole meeting
column5: Leduc council addressed and reviewed the Buddy character and post
column6: ultimately choosing to remove the spokesbud from the campaign. The announcement was made by the City of Leduc on September 25th

column2: 000+ and the campaign reaching such a large audience
column3: this became quite a large spectacle for the city with outlets such as CTV
column5: and CBC News covering the controversy.
